Dialogue.NPCText:
The man before you is burly, grim-faced, and has the wary look of someone who counts every coin—and every blade.

"Unless you're buying, move along. I've no time for chat, and less for charity."

He glances at your hands and belt, appraising you like merchandise.

Option.text: Looking for work, not small talk.
You fence weapons here, don’t you?
You seem like someone with a story.

Dialogue.NPCText:
He snorts. "Name's Veris. I move things the guards can't trace, sell what falls off the back of a wagon, and don't ask questions unless gold's involved.

Sunreach runs on trade and secrets. Me? I run on profit. Anything else?"

Option.text: Tell me about the city guard.

Dialogue.NPCText: He shrugs, expression flat. "Maybe I do, maybe I don't. But in Sunreach, everyone's buying from someone—and everyone owes someone. The question is: are you useful, or just curious?"

Option.text: Heard you cross Darius Veynar often.

Dialogue.NPCText: Veris lowers his voice. "City guard’s as crooked as a pirate's spine. Captain Merek plays both sides—takes bribes from the council, lets certain shipments vanish if you pay enough. I'd supply them myself if I could, but Merek blocks my deals at every turn."

Option.text: Want him out of the way?
You sound bitter. Why not join the council?

Dialogue.NPCText: A muscle ticks in his jaw. "Darius likes to play king with his silk and spices, but he’s not above buying my steel when the council needs it. Problem is, he also pays the guard captain to keep my crates 'lost.' Old game. Profits get smaller, knives get longer."
He laughs, mirthless. "If I wanted Darius dead, he'd be floating in the bay. No—business is business. I just want my fair share, and to get the guard captain off my back. That’s where you come in."

Veris spits. "Sit in a fancy chair, smile for the nobles, and get stabbed in the back before lunch? No thanks. I’d rather sell to them all and let ‘em fight over scraps. Money's safer than politics—most days."

He leans in, voice a whisper. "I want a contract with the city guard—official, above board. Problem is, Captain Merek claims I'm 'untrustworthy.' Hypocrite—he’s skimming half the armory for himself. If I had proof, the council would toss him to the sharks."

"Bring me evidence of the guard captain’s corruption—a ledgers page, a marked crate, anything I can show the council. In return, I'll pay you well—and maybe, just maybe, Sunreach gets a bit less rotten."

Option.text: How do I find this evidence?
What if the captain finds out?
This is too risky for me.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Try the guardhouse in the western docks—look for a chest with Merek’s seal, or check his desk for a secret ledger. If he spots you, play dumb or run. And watch out: the guard's loyalists bite harder than the pirates."

Option.text: I'm on it. I'll return with proof.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Merek keeps two ledgers. The real one’s bound in black leather, marked with his signet. Names, shipments, bribes—all in code, but I know what to look for. Bring me that, and the council will have no choice but to act."

Option.text: Understood. I'll get the black ledger.
I’ll see what I can do.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Once you have proof, bring it here. Keep your mouth shut—guards have long memories, and so do I. Do the job right, and you'll have gold and a friend in low places. Do it wrong… well, you'll wish you hadn't."

Option.text: On second thought, this isn't for me.

Dialogue.NPCText: He grimaces. "He arrested my brother once, then let him go for a sack of gold. Since then, he's blocked every deal I try to make. I don't need revenge—just want his claws off my business."
Veris narrows his eyes. "If the captain suspects you, deny everything or leave Sunreach until things cool off. But if you want easy gold, you're in the wrong city."

Option.text: Understood. Let's talk about the evidence.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Veris slides a sealed pouch toward you, eyes cold.

"Bring me that proof, and you'll have your cut. Fail, and I'll deny we ever spoke. Don't get caught."

Option.text: I'll be back when I have what you need.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Veris eyes you warily, then exhales through his nose.

"Story? Nah. Just years of doing things no one wants to talk about. But if you're that curious..."

Option.text: I am. You weren’t always a fence, were you?
Forget it. I didn’t mean to pry.

Dialogue.NPCText:
He leans back, gaze distant.

"Used to run arms for the Jhelom militias during the Mage Riots. Got my start smuggling crossbows inside fish crates. Clever, right? Till someone found a bolt in their trout."
He chuckles once, but there’s no humor in it.

Option.text: Interesting. But I don’t need war stories.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Veris grins, catching the edge in your voice.

"Proud? No. Profitable? Absolutely. Blood soaks everything eventually—better it be someone else’s."

Option.text: Fair point. Tell me the rest.

Dialogue.NPCText:
He flinches, just slightly. "Didn’t mean for it to go so far. But once the blades are moving, you either swing or get cut."
"I lost people. Friends. Even had someone I called ‘brother.’ Didn’t stop him from putting a dagger in my ribs when the gold dried up."

Option.text: So that’s why you trust no one.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"When the riots died down, I ran east. Took work on caravans, sold blades in Qasaria, even fenced relics from the jungle ruins. Met good folk. Met monsters too—sometimes in the same tavern."

"Eventually came here. Sunreach don’t ask questions if you make the coin flow. So I stayed."

Option.action: SendMessage:‘You feel the edge behind his words… a man built on scars.’

Option.text: You’ve survived a lot. I respect that.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Yeah. Name was Vargo. We’d split loot, share watches, bleed together. Then one job goes bad, and he cuts me loose like ballast."
"Took me three months to track him. Left what was left of him for the crows near Eldermoor."

"Wouldn’t you?" he snaps. "Trust gets you dead in my world. Gold, steel, silence—those are my friends."

He exhales slowly, voice softer.
“But… maybe you’re different. Maybe not.”

Option.text: I’ve got your back. If you’ve got mine.

Dialogue.NPCText:
He studies you a long moment, then nods.

"Alright. Maybe there’s still such a thing as loyalty in this city. But don’t make me regret it."

Option.text: You won’t. Now, what’s the job?

Dialogue.NPCText: "You want romance and honor? Go join the Paladins in Trinsic. I deal in steel and facts. Fact is—every honest man I ever met died poor and early."

Veris grunts, pushing off the wall.

"Enough memory lane. I’ve got crates to move, and you’ve got choices to make. If you're still interested, I've got work for a steady blade."
